Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:608H-GTN1-DXH2-63F6-00000-00Left Now Trying To Banish Fourth Of July; The Left's War On American Culture; President Trump's Reelection Prospects Related to U.S. Economic Performance Examined; Analyst Links Participants in Recent Protests to Elites against President Trump; New Study Shows Positive Effect of Hydroxychloroquine as Treatment for COVID-192020-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:08ZLexisNexisINGRAHAM ANGLE10:00 PM ESTScotty Smart, Horace Cooper, Mark Trammell, Tom Bevan, Sohrab Ahmari, Ramin OskouiNEWSDomestic070201cb.257Left Now Trying To Banish Fourth Of July; The Left's War On American Culture; President Trump's Reelection Prospects Related to U.S. Economic Performance Examined; Analyst Links Participants in Recent Protests to Elites against President Trump; New Study Shows Positive Effect of Hydroxychloroquine as Treatment for COVID-19Raymond Arroyo, Mike Huckabee

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS HOST: At Mount Rushmore, and much more. But before we go, I wanted to say that our thoughts and prayers are with Herman Cain as he battles COVID-19.

Make sure you set your DVR. But the "Ingraham Angle" is up next. Raymond Arroyo is in the chair tonight, Raymond. It's all yours.

RAYMOND ARROYO, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey, Jason. Great show. Thanks. And happy July 4th. We'll see you.

CHAFFETZ: Thanks.

ARROYO: I'm Raymond Arroyo in for Laura Ingraham tonight, and this is a special edition of the "Ingraham Angle." Record breaking jobs numbers coming out today, but that's not enough to make the left happy. You'll hear why Biden thinks job growth is a bad thing. Mike Huckabee and Tom Bevan are here.

Plus, radicals screaming in the faces of police, destroying property and getting violent. What do we really know about these peaceful protesters? What's driving them? And citizens fight back against COVID regulations as we approach July 4th.

Breaking tonight a bombshell COVID drug study. I'm borrowing Laura's medicine cabinet for this one. We'll bring all the details to you.

But first, "State of Emergency." Last night we told you about political efforts to stymie your public celebration of July 4th. But now there are efforts to banish the holiday all together. More beach closures were announced today in Orange County, California. Fireworks and parades have been canceled all over the country.

Patriotism has now joined religion as a second-class practice, one subjected to draconian restrictions, not applied to other activities owing to COVID fears. But the application of these public health restrictions, that's what they're calling them, are selectively employed and riddled with politics.

In California, politicians are using emergency regulations to stop families from beachfront cookouts.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR ERIC GARCETTI (D-CA), LOS ANGELES: I know that we love seeing those firework exhibitions, but not this year. This year, we have to think about saving lives to protect what we have in this country, to protect who we are--

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: But this was the scene in Los Angeles today. They couldn't be packed closer together. Now, given this coddling of protesters, nobody bothered them. People should jam the streets with patriotic protests this weekend.

Amazingly, the same public health emergency powers are being invoked to dismantle markers of American history as we approach July 4th. In Richmond, Virginia. The Democrat Mayor Levar Stoney ordered the removal of a series of Confederate statues. That came down yesterday. You probably heard very little about it.

Now, however you feel about those statues, the people of Richmond should decide the fate of these public works by a vote. But the mayor cited public health and safety as the reason for the statues removal. Listen,

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MAYOR LEVAR STONEY (D-VA), RICHMOND: We believe that we're on sound legal ground. On June 8th, the City Council evoked another declaration of emergency under our emergency operations plans. The mayor is the Emergency Management Director. We're in the state of emergency until July 29th. And I'm going to do everything necessary - it's my responsibility to do everything necessary to ensure that we protect life and property.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Especially the life and property of the protesters, not its constituents. The Richmond Mayor justified his decision to "The Wall Street Journal" this way. "As the COVID-19 pandemic continues to surge, and protesters attempt to take down Confederate statues themselves or confront others who are doing so, the risk grows for serious illness, injury, or death."

So let me get this straight mobs endangering themselves or threatening others is the justification for taking down public works of art. I see. Now, was Stonewall Jackson spreading COVID? Then how do COVID emergency powers apply in this case?

Say there's a mob who wants to lower taxes, could those COVID emergency powers be used to lower them? I'm checking for a friend. Look, this is mob rule. And these liberal politicians are giving them exactly what they want, while silencing their citizenry. Richmond residents get to say nothing. They are stuck in the house because of COVID.

Now, this July 4th, while you're sitting at home, watching firework reruns, or older clips of singers on TV, one type of parade will be allowed with no disruptions at all. In Tampa, Chicago, Carson City, Washington DC, and possibly elsewhere, there are planned "Boycott the 4th" and "The Hell With the 4th Of July!" protests planned. That's right.

Black Lives Matter protesters don't want you to celebrate July 4th. We're going to debate that in moments with one of the organizers. The webpage for the DC protest bills it as the birth of a new nation. The idea being that Black Americans and none of us should be celebrating July 4th, because not everyone was free at the signing of the Declaration. Never mind that everyone's free now, especially protesters. This is a movement rooted in division on the day set aside to celebrate our unity.

Incidentally, the DC protesters are demanding reparations for offspring of indigenous people or slaves in a lump sum or quarterly stimulus check payments please; free health care for all citizens; and J. Edgar Hoover's name removed from the FBI headquarters, at least their original.

The problem is, Americans are now absorbing this idea that they're somehow not part of this great American holiday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: July 4th should not even be celebrated in the first place. It's a racist holiday.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: 4th of July in American history is an all-White holiday. Whereas Juneteenth is a celebration of black culture.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Juneteenth makes more sense, right? The rest of America, they want the 4th of July, they can have it. But I think as a as a Black person, freedom came on Juneteenth.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Hmm. We'll explore this in our next segment. But we are all one people, Black, White, and everything in between. July 4th belongs to anyone who embraces the American ideal founded in liberty. We cannot be a nation of perpetual grievance and unforgiveable sins. Independence Day is a day to recall the principles and spirit that bring us together.

But this year, it's being exploited as an occasion to drive us apart. And in the COVID regulations, and we see the nation on edge. And later we'll get to the ways citizens are fighting back against this arbitrary isolation and the masking.

But after months, it's pushed people to the limit and it's turned politically. If you're worried about being infected or you're ill, please stay home. But your COVID concerns are not a license to attack or harass fellow citizens who are just as free as you are, to exercise their rights and take their own risks.

I mean, I even saw people at the grocery today at a Costco, they're elbowing, yelling at each other, put the mask on, or get in line or stay away from me. And the government should be careful as well. In the way they invoke these emergency orders to constrict the movement of people in the United States of America.

As you know, the President is attending a big fireworks display outdoors at Mount Rushmore Friday night. We'll be bringing you live coverage of that event. It promises to be a moment of normalcy in a year that's been anything but. And right on cue Dr. Fauci shows up to discourage attendance.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Masks will not be mandated, nor will social distancing. What is your message to political leaders and people who are insisting on holding events like this in this environment?

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES: Avoid crowds, wear a mask, keep physical distance. It doesn't matter what the reason for the congregation, whether it's a celebration here, the demonstration there, it doesn't make any difference, wear a mask.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: If all Americans, protesters and everyday citizens, were treated alike that guidance might be better received, but they aren't. There are two rules at play. One for protesters and rioters and another for law abiders.

This holiday weekend, every American is entitled to celebrate as they see fit, calculating the risk, whether raising a fist or waving a flag. It is this great country that allows us that freedom. It deserves our respect, and to be celebrated boldly this weekend.

Joining me now is Horace Cooper of Project 21, the Co-Chair and Author of "How Trump is Making Black America Great Again." Also, with me is Scotty Smart. He's founder of the Smart Foundation. Thank you both for being here.

Scotty, you were supposed to speak at a "Forget the Fourth" event in Atlanta. What do you intend to achieve by doing this? I know you're having some health difficulties and may not be able to attend. But what are these protests designed to do exactly?

SCOTTY SMART, FOUNDER, THE SMART FOUNDATION: Well, these protests are designed to educate people, and to make sure that we have a unity amongst ourselves. When we say Forget the Fourth, a lot of people try to strategically change narrative and make it a hate rhetoric against the Constitution or against the flag and things like that. And that's what it's not.

But it's also to make sure that we hold America accountable for saying that it provides liberty and justice for us all, which we as Black people don't feel that we are getting in this country. And so when we go to celebrations like this, we voice our opinions and voice ourselves. Because if you look at the history of this country, which a lot of times people try to overlook, it has nothing that been great for Black people.

Since 1776 when the Declaration of Independence was signed, we haven't necessarily been treated as equals. And so as we move forward--

ARROYO: So Scotty - so wait a minute, Scotty. So you don't believe Black Americans can celebrate the 4th of July? Is that what you're saying? I mean, you're carving Black America out of the 4th of July, or that's what you'd like to do?

SMART: I'm not carving out anything. Anyone is free to celebrate however they would like to celebrate. What I'm saying is that we weren't free and our independence - on the 4th of July when the Declaration of Independence was signed, so therefore, we aren't celebrating it. For me personally. Anyone is able to--

ARROYO: OK.

SMART: Go ahead.

ARROYO: I got to get - I got to let Horace in this Scotty. Horace, your reaction. Is July 4th not a holiday for Black Americans or one they shouldn't take part here.

HORACE COOPER, CO-CHAIRMAN, PROJECT 21: This is patent nonsense. First of all, Black Americans, like White Americans, are going to be overwhelmingly on the roads this weekend. We're going to be setting a record of the number of people getting together with their loved ones to celebrate.

Secondly, at - in 1776, there were thousands of free Black men who joined in the fight to help secure liberty and freedom. It is an absolute insult to the sacrifice that those people made to say that we were not "free." Some are free, some are not free.

Now, all our free. America has lived up to the model that it set up. This experiment has been remarkably successful. And this weekend is a time that we should all be coming together to celebrate that success.

ARROYO: Scotty, what's wrong with that?

SMART: I don't even think Horace to actually believe that what he's saying himself. So let's give Horace a history lesson about Black Americans in this country, because he said it's 1776 that we were free. But Horace, we weren't free until 1865. Is that not correct?

ARROYO: No, he said some people were free.

COOPER: That is not true.

SMART: The Thirteenth Amendment--

COOPER: See, that's not true. You don't know your history. Stay away from eating the tide pods - stay away from meeting the tide pods and look at the history book. And what you will see is there are a number of Black Americans throughout history who stood on the side of freedom and liberty. This celebration is for everyone who supports liberty. It is not for Whites, it's not for Blacks.

ARROYO: Horace, I want to let Scotty - let Scotty get in here. Go ahead.

SMART: So when we talk history, and we talk about the abolishment of slavery with The Thirteenth Amendment, even then, right after that we have Black Codes, which legally made us slave still, because they do incarcerate us for not having homes and not having jobs at that time.

And then as you move forward through our history, you don't get civil rights and you don't get voter acts until 1965. And so when you go to that point of our history, which is 100 years later, now we're in modern day history. And then talk about how the government has strategically, always systematically--

ARROYO: Yes, but Scotty - so Scotty, I think - Yes, I think I think Horace's his point is America has fulfilled the promise. It wasn't fully fulfilled early on, but it has been now. Black Americans are - Louis Armstrong is as much a part of the American story as Jackie Robinson and George Washington at this point.

Two Republican senators, I want to get into this. Two Republican senators Ron Johnson and James Lankford have put forward a bill to replace Columbus Day as a federal holiday with Juneteenth. This is Senator Johnson or he said rather, "Wee celebrating emancipation with a federal holiday, but we believe we should eliminate a current holiday in exchange. We chose Columbus Day as a holiday that's lightly celebrated, and least disruptive."

Here's my here's my question, Juneteenth came two and a half years after the Emancipation Proclamation. OK? The Thirteenth Amendment was actually ratified on December 6, 1865, so should we be celebrating (INAUDIBLE)? I mean, is that what we should be celebrating? I'll let you both get a crack at that. Is that what you want, Scotty? You want Juneteenth and no more 4th of July?

SMART: Juneteenth is a celebration of freedom for us, and I think that is something that should be a national holiday. I appreciate people stepping up and taking that stance. But even then, we talk about systematic oppression throughout the entire history of America, we still haven't gotten equality and justice for all or liberty and justice for all, as the Constitution says.

So you can look through systematic oppression, through poverty, through probation through, mass incarceration, you can look at several instances within our climate that are controlled by systematic oppression and white supremacy that has not afforded Black--

(CROSSTALK)

ARROYO: I need to let Horace get in here Scotty. Yes, I need to let - go ahead, Horace, you respond.

COOPER: All the Left wing, Marxists drivel aside. There is a fact. The fact is America gave more lives in the Civil War than in any war America has ever been a part of. And as a result of that war, three constitutional amendments came about.

And as a result of that, America joined together and ultimately has said that it is going to commit - and has done so, committed to the idea that we did at our inception. Every citizen is going to be recognized and supported equally before the law. What they're wanting to do now is to throw that away, and yet, it ignores the marvel of what our country is all about.

ARROYO: Scotty, I'll give you 30 seconds to respond.

SMART: Thank you. There's no that that's true Horace.

COOPER: It's a fact.

SMART: There's completely injustice within our systematic approach to criminal justice. Black people don't get the same sentences as Whites. You have someone that it was just released who did - who was sentenced to 1,000 years in jail for child pornography that just was - only did seven years was paroled yesterday.

You have a Black man in Kansas that was sentenced to 12 years for kissing a young White girl, but there was no DNA evidence found upon him. So make sure when you talk facts that you have your facts correct. And you don't use your talking points to make sure you get your paycheck.

ARROYO: Go ahead Horace. You got to respond.

COOPER: These are talking points. Read my book - read my book and you'll see a 100-year history of the progress of Americans who happen to be black by policies that are great for all of all of America.

ARROYO: OK, we're going to leave it there gentleman. And Scotty, Horace, I want you all to come together and celebrate this great country that allows us to converse like this and allows us to support and love one another. And happy July 4th to both of you. Thank you for being here.

Across the country Americans are fighting to protect their rights and to free themselves from COVID lockdowns by appealing to the courts. Now, yesterday, a Wisconsin judge overturned the City of Racine's COVID-19 ordinance ruling it. "Likely the strictest and most overreaching COVID-19 order or ordinance in the country." Judge Jon Fredrickson also said that, "no average person of ordinary intelligence can make sense of its sprawling breadth."

It banned public gatherings and much more. This comes after the Wisconsin Supreme Court threw out the Democratic governor's stay at home orders after Republican lawmakers sued over them.

Joining me now is Mark Trammell. He is the Executive Director and General Counsel of the Center for American Liberty. Now, Mark, Americans seem to be pushing back on these blue states and city officials who used COVID to increase their power at the expense of the public's liberties. What are these cases? And that religious liberty case last week in New York where Cuomo and de Blasio were slapped down? What do they tell us about where the courts are now?

MARK TRAMMELL, CO-CHAIR, CENTER FOR AMERICAN LIBERTY: Well, thank you, Raymond, for having me on the program. You're absolutely right. Americans are fighting back, because I think everyone is fed up at this point.

And, you know, let me just start by saying, the Center for American Liberty, we're challenging these restrictions across the country. And kudos to this judge in Wisconsin for getting it right, for having the courage to say that while public health is absolutely very important, and something that we're trying to achieve in this COVID era. But at the same time, they have to act within constitutional bounds. And what happened in Wisconsin, they violated the First Amendment. It was unconstitutionally vague. It was overbroad, and this judge got it right.

ARROYO: OK. In Los Angeles and Ventura, we touched on this earlier, those counties are closing their beaches this weekend. Here's how la Mayor Garcetti wants you to spend your July 4th instead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GARCETTI: Everyone should cancel their in-person plans for July 4th. Gatherings with people who do not live in your household are not allowed. You know how to express your patriotism this year? It's not going to be a firework show. It's not going to be at the barbecue. It's going to be wearing a mask and keeping your distance.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Sounds like a barrel of laughs. I'm sure that's exactly how people want to celebrate July 4th. Mark, you filed a lawsuit challenging these beach closures on what grounds?

TRAMMELL: Absolutely. Well, it violates the California State Constitution. Article 10 Section 4 actually gives residents of California a constitutional right to access the beaches.

ARROYO: OK. In Palm Beach residents are suing the county over their mandatory mask policy. Now it alleges that the policy infringes on their constitutional rights and forces them to wear quote harmful medical devices like mask.

Now, Laura Ingraham always says, this is a speech issue, because it limits your ability to communicate and it runs afoul of a host of basic rights. Can you force people to wear masks constitutionally?

TRAMMELL: You know, I think that's still a question that's being debated. And I think that if we look at the way these cases are playing out broadly, I think courts are going to come down on both sides of that issue, because, certainly in situations mask can be communicative and expressive and have first amendment implications.

ARROYO: OK, I got to get to this in Rockland County, New York. The host of a house party came down with COVID. Now the party goers are refusing to talk with the COVID tracers. Remember those people hired to go track down the disease? Now the COVID treasures are threatening action. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. PATRICIA SCHNABEL RUPPERT, ROCKLAND COUNTY HEALTH COMMISSIONER: Most people do cooperate with us. But for the smaller number that do not, they have hung up on us, given us a very small amount of information--

I needed to send eight subpoenas yesterday to obtain the required information for our contact investigations. It worked.

KATE BOLDUAN, CNN ANCHOR: Right away, because it was threatening what was it a $2,500-$2,000 fine for every day that they didn't respond?

RUPPERT: Up to $2,000 per day.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Can they - can a contract tracer force people with subpoenas to divulge their private whereabouts, personal information? Very quickly.

TRAMMELL: Yes, this raises a lot of constitutional concern - right to privacy, due process. It's fraught with problems, absolutely, Raymond.

ARROYO: Mark, I thank you coming up. Authorities have caught the alleged ringleader on that attack on Andrew Jackson statue in DC and more. Plus, we'll get into all the polls with Mike Huckabee, Tom Bevan. Stay right there.

ARROYO: Welcome back to "The Ingraham Angle." I'm Raymond Arroyo. An update to our anti-American most wanted list. The FBI and U.S. Park Service today arrested the man, who they say, orchestrated the attack on President Andrew Jackson's statue in Lafayette Park last week.

Sources tell fox news that Jason Charter was arrested this morning at his home. He's since been charged with destruction of federal property. Now this comes just days after the feds arrested four other men for their alleged involvement in the same statue attack.

The authorities did not use ropes or spray paint during those apprehensions. All were allegedly caught in photos or on tape, partaking in the destruction at the insistence of ringleader, Jason Charter.

A federal law enforcement source says. "They were very organized. Charter was on top of the statute, directing people. They had acid, chisels, straps and a human chain, preventing police from getting to the statue."

Now, the FBI also alleges that charter took part in destroying the statue of Confederate officer Andrew (ph) Pike in DC. The bureau claims surveillance footage shows Charter standing over the toppled Pike statue, pouring an unknown liquid onto the statue. He is then observed waving others away and squatting behind the sculpture. Seconds later, the statue catches fire charges. Charter seen standing over the flames as it burns.

Now, after this incident, the FBI says Charter posted a picture of the statue burning on Twitter with this caption, "Tearing down statues of traitors to the nation is a service to this nation, not a crime." On Facebook, he posted the same picture, this time writing sweetly, "Death to all Confederate statues."

Sources tell Fox that charter has ties to Antifa, the radical anarchist group behind much of the mayhem and destruction we've seen over the past few weeks. Now last week, President Trump issued an Executive Order to prosecute anyone who desecrates military monuments to the fullest extent of the law.

Lesson of the day. Public statues are not your private domain. Keep your hands, your ropes and your flammables off. Here's some more good news.

Today's record-breaking jobs numbers smashed expectations. In June, the economy added a whopping 4.8 million jobs, which is 1.8 million more than economists predicted. The unemployment rate fell to 11.1 percent, which is still high, but a massive improvement from last month. President Trump rightfully celebrated the news.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The United States economy has added almost 5 million new jobs in the month of June. That's shattering all expectations and shattering all record. America's economy is now roaring back to life like nobody's ever seen before. Nobody's going to shatter the American dream.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: But Joe Biden is downplaying the record-breaking boom.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We're filling a deep, deep job hole because Donald Trump has so badly bungled the response to coronavirus. Only one-third of the jobs that were lost in March and April have now come back. Until this President faces what's going on in our country, our economy is going to remain at risk.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: I'm worried Joe Biden's confusing his deep, deep hole with the economy, but maybe we can sort that out. Joining me now is Tom Bevan. He's Co-Founder and president of RealClearPolitics. Also with me is Mike Huckabee, former Arkansas Governor and Fox News Contributor.

Governor, our economy is bouncing back. Why is Biden so unhappy? I mean, it doesn't look bad for him to be dissing the economic recovery?

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I think it's simple, Raymond. You know, Joe Biden doesn't want the economy to come back strong. Because he knows that, as the President gets credit for having built a strong economy before the terrible virus shut everything down, that's why we're bouncing back.

It was falling like an anvil, but it's coming back like it was on a bungee cord only because the tax policy, deregulation, and aggressive dealings with China and other cheating nations gave us an incredibly strong economy as if we're on rocket fuel. Now, because it was strong, it is coming back and Joe Biden has nothing to take credit for. Nothing whatsoever.

ARROYO: Tom, I want to get into those national polls in a moment, but Trump is polling higher in almost every poll on the economy, higher than Biden. How important is that and will it be to this reelection bid?

TOM BEVAN, REAL CLEAR POLITICS CO-FOUNDER: It's usage. It's his strongest suit. And if you want to know why, Trump, he's still almost at 50 percent in our Real Clear Politics average on his handling of the economy, and his approval of the economy. His approval of his handling of the coronavirus is down around 40 percent. And so that's why Joe Biden doesn't want to talk about the economy. He wants to shift the narrative back to the coronavirus because that's where Trump is weakest. And obviously, Trump wants to highlight these numbers. And he's going to need a strong economy over the next four months to really press that case because it is by far right now his biggest asset in terms of winning the election.

ARROYO: Yes. We are hearing a lot about the national Trump/Biden matchups. Currently, Real Clear Politics, the average, has Biden up nine points on Trump nationally. Tom, what are the most important metrics we should be and focused on here instead of that overarching head-to-head?

BEVAN: Well, obviously, as we learned in 2016 and if you follow the elections, you know we don't have a national election. We have state elections. And so there are six key battleground states that everybody is focused on right now. They are Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, and then Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin. And that's where the election is going to be decided.

And so really focus on where the race is in those states. And right now Trump is behind in those states anywhere from about three percent to seven percent. Actually, it's not so different from where he was at this point in 2016 against Hillary Clinton.

ARROYO: Exactly.

BEVAN: But he is certainly now in a position of being the underdog. But again, the election is not held tomorrow. It's being held four months from now. There's still a lot of time.

ARROYO: Governor, I want your reaction to the media's take on these polls. Watch this and then react, please.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NICOLLE WALLACE, MSNBC HOST: There is no precedent, at least in modern times, for the comeback the president must mount.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Polling indicates this isn't even working for his base.

JOE SCARBOROUGH, MSNBC HOST: When historians look back, they're not going to have any question as to why Donald Trump's poll numbers collapsed the way that they did.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Governor, your thoughts?

HUCKABEE: I think they are celebrating a little too soon. It reminds me of 2016. I don't know how many times, even on FOX, I had arguments with other FOX personalities and hosts because they said there was no pathway for Donald Trump to win. Raymond, I kept saying he is going to win, he is going to win, and I was called an idiot for saying it.

But here's what I saw. Most of the people saying what they were saying are the people you just showed. They live in the bubbles of Washington and New York and Silicon Valley and Hollywood. They don't live out in the middle of America where people are sick and tired of the swamp. Donald Trump has a lot of people who support him, who are not going to tell a pollster, they're not going to put a yard sign up because they don't want to be called a racist or a xenophobe or whatever "phobe" is popular today. But they are going to go vote for him because they know that he is fighting for them, and they realized Joe Biden doesn't even know there is a fight going on.

ARROYO: Laura, I spoke to her earlier today, and she said the Biden choice means your taxes are going up and Mount Rushmore is coming down. How might this rioting and destruction of statues affect this race, Tom?

BEVAN: Yes, look, this is rapidly becoming the backup. I think the economy is still going to be a major factor, but this race is also morphing into even beyond protests and police reform. It has now become a contest of do you think America is a great country and a great place to live, and are you thankful to be a part of it, or do you think America -- do you not like America? Do you hate America? Do you think it's a flawed, oppressive society?

And that's where I think Donald Trump actually, that's not bad ground for him to run on, because Joe Biden may not be a radical, but he is going to represent those radical elements of the Democratic Party. And that is the choice -- elections are usually, when the reelection are referendum on the incumbent, that's what this is going to be for Donald Trump, at least it is right now. The Trump campaign wants to make it a choice and say, look, you may not like my style, you may not like things about me, but if you don't want to vote for me, you have got to vote for this. And they want that to be -- Joe Biden is going to represent all of that, whether it's the economic policy or whether it's the cultural issues that are in play there, that's the debate that is going to take place.

ARROYO: It feels a lot like 1968 where Nixon tied all of the mayhem to his Democratic challenger. Governor Huckabee, a new "USA Today" poll shows there's a massive enthusiasm gap between Biden and Trump. Here's the breakdown, 50 percent of Trump voters are very excited while only 27 percent of Biden voters say the same. How do you think that's going to affect turnout and the final tally, governor?

HUCKABEE: Raymond, that is a big, big factor in an election. You always want to have the momentum on your side in terms of your voters will swim across the river at flood stage to go vote for you. And if there is a drop of rain, Biden supporters are going to stay home. I don't see any enthusiasm for him. The only thing Biden can honestly say is, hey, I'm not Donald Trump for you people who hate Donald Trump.

But what he can't say is, listen to my great vision for America. I've been in politics for 50 years, and I have nothing to show for it except I'm a terrible plagiarist and have been caught time and again stealing other people's material. That's his claim to fame. I don't think it pans out like people think it does. Yes, the president needs to rev it up a little bit, change some things. But I believe he is going to win.

ARROYO: I want both of you to react very quickly. A new group was formed this week. Former George W. Bush officials are banning together to support Joe Biden. Now, did any of these people vote for Hillary Clinton last time? That's what I want to know. Is this the kiss of death for Biden? Tom Bevan first, then the governor.

(LAUGHTER)

BEVAN: Is this the kiss of death for Biden? No, it's not the kiss of death for Biden, and it's certainly not the kiss of death for Donald Trump either. These kinds of groups get a lot of attention in the media, but they don't represent overall a huge number of people. It's a marginal thing, not going to make a difference.

ARROYO: Governor, we saw physicians, scientists, generals come out against Trump in the last election. None of it had any effect. Will this effort work?

HUCKABEE: It only revs his base up more. And to those people who think they are important, here is my reaction -- we'll see you after the election.

(LAUGHTER)

ARROYO: A wonderful place to leave it, but save the yawns until the end of the hour, Governor.

(LAUGHTER)

ARROYO: Tom, Governor Huckabee, thank you both for being here.

Up next, we ask the question, what do these protesters really want, and who are they? The answer that you have not been told about.

And breaking news on the COVID therapy front. We'll share new info, a great new study, when we return. Stay there.

ARROYO: Welcome back to "The Ingraham Angle." The protests in New York City are not dying down, despite the city's promise to cut the police budget. In fact, in terms of rhetoric, things seem to be heating up. Poor policeman.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Take that badge off, they'll shoot you, too. They don't care about me. Take it off, they'll kill you next. They don't care about you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Think they care about your thug --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If he doesn't know you have a badge, they'll kill you. They don't like you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: What kind of person harasses -- what kind of person harasses a police officer that way? And a black officer no less? And who would attend a protest night after night to do the same? Senator Mike Lee took a stab at answering those questions today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. MIKE LEE, (R-UT): Dimwitted, phony drama addicts, failed by an education system and addled by a social media culture that taught them to be victims instead of citizens. A privileged, self-absorbed, crime syndicate trying to find meaning in empty lives by destroying things that other Americans have spent honest, productive lives building.

(END VIDEO CLIP).

ARROYO: My next guest says what we're seeing play out is not a Marxist revolution, but something far broader. And it has everything to do with Donald Trump. Joining me now is Sohrab Ahmari. He's the op-ed editor at "The New York Post" and author of the forthcoming "The Broken Thread, Discovering the Wisdom of Tradition in an Age of Chaos." Boy, do we need that. Sohrab, we have been led to believe that these are Marxist protesters. Now, you just wrote a new piece in "The Spectator" that makes a very different case. Who are these counterrevolutionaries?

SOHRAB AHMARI, "NEW YORK POST" OP-ED EDITOR: I think there are elements in these movements that are from the hard left, Antifa, other such groups. But what I argue is, first of all, if you see New York and you are in New York like I am, you see a lot of is, let's say, middle-class, upper middle- class, children of the bourgeoisie is some ways. But even beyond that, looking at who is actually in the streets, what's interesting to me is who is supporting this. I don't deny that there is a grassroots element, but I also see it mainly, in a very telling way, as revolution what you might call the laptop class, or the neoliberal elite, people are in the professional managerial class, big tech, large corporations, academia, quote-unquote, the expert class.

These are all people who were threatened by 2016, which I think was the real revolution. That was the year that voters both here in the United States but also in Europe voted for movements like President Donald Trump, for Brexit, other populist and conservative nationalist movements. And they turfed out a kind of global elite, for the first time they turfed them out of power in decades. And they saw that as a threat.

And so in the four years that followed, Raymond, they did one thing after another. You'll remember, starting with a collusion probe, then you had the farcical impeachment process. Then in Britain, you had three years of trying to thwart what the British people had decisively chosen at the ballot box, which is to leave the European Union. And I see this as one more element of that process. Everything else has been tried. And if that happens -- and I'm not saying it is a conspiracy. It's just a tendency of a certain class.

ARROYO: So it's a class war. You are really saying this is a class war. And the question is, why our big companies like Brooks Brothers, Walmart, Netflix, why are they signing onto this movement, Sohrab? It would seem it would undermine their outcomes, it would undermine and their well-being.

AHMARI: Again, I'm not so sure, because I think the people who are making these decisions for these companies are not dumb. So, if they don't act against their own interest, someone really has to ask, if anyone seriously believes that revolution that threatens the interest of the American establishment, like you said, Walmart, Amazon, Nike, Netflix, the trustees of Ivy League universities, Brooks Brothers, for God's sake, if a movement really threatened those interest materially, would they support it? They wouldn't. I would argue that their material interest lies in things like easier trade with China. And so President Trump and movements like President Trump's in Europe like Brexit have thrown a wrench in their economic workings. And so --

ARROYO: Very quickly, Sohrab, but the breakdown of the policing and the call to disband the police and defund it, that doesn't quite fit this theory, though, does it?

AHMARI: Again, I think it does, because, look, some of the wealthiest people in my social circle are also the ones who are supporting defund the police, and it's because they can afford private security. They live in doorman buildings.

ARROYO: Private security, doesn't affect them. It's always personal, Sohrab. We'll leave it there. Thank you so much. We'll have you back.

We will drive next into the breaking new COVID treatment study that confirms what "The Ingraham Angle" has been telling you for months. Details in moments, and an important programming note. Do not miss this. Stay there.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Not only does hydroxychloroquine not work to fight COVID, it can actually make patients sicker and even more likely to die.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There is no evidence that tells us that taking hydroxychloroquine is either safe or effective.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There is right now, to be clear, no evidence that it works to treat this disease.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: Well, a new hydroxychloroquine study has just dropped, and it could have all those experts eating their words. The Henry Ford Health System in Michigan tonight is announcing that hydroxychloroquine significantly reduced death rates among sick and hospitalized COVID patients. In this much anticipated study, researchers analyzed the health outcomes of 2,451 patients over a six-month period. They found that only 13 percent of COVID patients given hydroxychloroquine died, while 26 percent of non-hydroxy patients succumbed to the disease.

Joining me now is Dr. Ramin Oskoui. He is a cardiologist and CEO of Foxhall Cardiology. Doctor, how big is the study for hydroxychloroquine?

DR. RAMIN OSKOUI, CARDIOLOGIST: I think, as President Trump said, it's a game changer in the United States. We have seen excellent outcomes with hydroxychloroquine in Italy, in Spain, in France, in Turkey, Morocco. It seems as though the people that you quoted refused to read any literature that isn't generated inside the United States of America, inside the continental United States. The study shows not just that this drug halves mortality in patients with symptomatic COVID infections, but also it's incredibly safe when used with azithromycin, which is what we've seen in the Northwell Group in Long Island, and we've seen in France with Didier Raoult's 3,700 patient study that was published late last month.

ARROYO: This was a big one, and Dr. Oskoui, I want to dig a bit into this study and what it found regarding heart problems, the researchers write "A review of our COVID-19 data demonstrated no major cardiac arrhythmias, specifically no torsades de pointed that has been observed with hydroxychloroquine treatment." This would seem to totally refute the media narrative on this, Doc.

OSKOUI: It does. And it points to the fact that many of the studies that suggested there may have been a problem with hydroxychloroquine in this regard and the safety signals that supposed the FDA was concerned about were unfounded. As we've mentioned before, the Northwell Group in Long Island found no problem. I coauthored a letter to the editor of the British Medical Journal that reviewed this matter in depth. And the truth is that much of those issues probably occur because of sloppy medical care by the providers and using this drug in patients where it was not appropriate, basically patients who were essentially a few steps from the morgue.

ARROYO: Well, all I can say, when I read this, I thought our personal hydroxychloro-queen, Laura, would love this, seeing this report, so said she's not here.

CNN medical analyst and Cheney cardiologist Jonathan Reiner says Trump was foolish to put all of his hopes and hydroxy. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JONATHAN REINER, CNN MEDICAL ANALYST: He banked on magical thinking that the warm weather was going to make this go away, that hydroxychloroquine was a magic bullet. And he wished it away, and this is where we are.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ARROYO: The good doctor might have been engaging in magical thinking. What does this mean for remdesivir, Dr. Oskoui?

OSKOUI: I know Jonathan. He's an outstanding clinical cardiologist whose great skills are in the lab, but I think this makes remdesivir irrelevant. Remdesivir has never shown that it drops viral load, it never shows any mortality benefit. We have numerous studies that show this benefit with hydroxychloroquine when used in patients with mild or moderate COVID illness. And I think remdesivir, we bought, apparently, the U.S. supply, we bought something that was worthless. But we can share it with the world. I think the fact that we have 60 million tablets in the strategic reserve is going to great for the southern states where this is going to be desperately needed right now.

ARROYO: Doctor, I have to get roll. I've got a hard break. Thank you for your time.

President Trump is following in the footsteps of a past commander in chief. Find out who. Stay there.

ARROYO: It's time for the last bat. President Trump is taking cues from a past president who is a little out of fashion with the woke left. I'm talking about Teddy Roosevelt who used to say speak softly and carry a big stick. Well, Trump may not be speaking softly, but he was swinging a big stick at a Spirit of America White House event today. He's got that Babe Ruth vibe going.
